climbs.name: Swiss Movement
climbs.fa: Elise Ringgenberg, Karin Bates, Joe Terravecchia 07/2019

content.description: Climb straight up thin face holds up to some bigger ledges above.Thin sustained climbing around the corner from the Roost and the Nose. Great protection once you are on the route, a runout scramble from climber's left to reach the first bolt. Thin hands and feet until you reach the crux about 2/3 of the way up, where feet get even thinner. Dirty last couple of moves to the anchor.
content.protection: Well protected: Bolts all the way up every 5-10 feet, 7 bolts and 2-bolt anchor w/ links at the top
content.location: Located on the slab just left of Hymie's last stand. Located climber's right and around the corner from The Nose. Belay from the far left side of the route at a tree ledge. First 20 feet of the route are easy class 3-4 scramble up and to the right before the first bolt.

content.description: Just to the right of The Roost there is a bulge, climb over that  with no pro stopping you from hitting the ground, though you can place a cam so that you don't pull you and your belay off the ledge. Continue straight up the slab to the top of the cliff.
content.protection: Tricams, standard rack (you're not going to use a lot of it)
content.location: Between the Roost and the Nose, closer to the Nose.

content.description: Probably the best route on the Luna wall. The route originally climbed right at the 4th bolt into the shallow dihedral,12d. Going straight up here keeps the grade at about 12b and is more consistent with the rest of the route.
content.protection: 9 bolts to LO.
content.location: Starts 10' to the right of Luna.

content.description: Easy slab to fun face climbing just right of the arching crack.
content.protection: 6 bolts. Some climbers may want  to bring a medium size cam for the bottom of the crack to protect the moves to the 2nd bolt.
content.location: Belay at the hemlock tree just around the corner from the base of the Nose.

content.description:
The right facing corner in the middle of Stonehouse's main face. 

  Well protected laybacking up the full length of the corner. Starts at the base of the corner, follow up on laybacks and face holds behind and above you. Belay from a tree further back, or hand sized cams just below the top. 

  A variation goes from near the top of the corner, but traverses right after the vertical step. Makes for really fun, airy moves out right on good feet, with hands in a horizontal. Good gear, good hands, and an airy feeling. Great climbing, finish as for The Nose (5.8).
content.protection: Single rack of camalots .3-2, nuts or hexes as you please. Two alright-looking fixed pitons mid-route. Smaller cams available, as is wider, but not necessary.
content.location:
The large right facing corner that starts on the left side of the large ledge that holds the start to Joke Book (5.9) and The Nose (5.8).  

  Walk off the top, or rappel off a tree back from the topout. No fixed anchor or slings/links/rings on the tree.

content.description: The obvious rounded arete that forms the center divider for the cliff.     Mostly if not all fixed gear (bolts and pins)
content.protection: Bolts and Pins   Maybe a few pieces?
content.location: Center of the cliff.   Starts off of the upper launch pad.

climbs.name: Moe Howard Died For Our Sins

content.description: Great rock and  wonderful varied climbing  easily make this one of the best of the harder lines at Stonehouse. The route starts with a difficult  sequence of underclings and crimps  past 1 pin and 3 bolts to a sit down rest . Above, climb smooth marble like stone on good edges.
content.protection: 1 pin, 6 bolts and a .4  BD cam or medium sized nut for the horizontal near the top.  LO  Anchors.
content.location: Located on the gently overhanging wall on left side of the cliff.  The route starts 20' right of the BBB Route ( a crack climb with a bolt at its base).  Although partially shaded by large hemlocks, during the summer months  this side of the cliff loses the sun entirely by around 1:00.

content.description: Sustained  crimps and slopers, long reaches and multiple cruxes. Decent rest at the undercling. Originally rated 12a in 1992, consensus seems to be 2 or 3 letter grades higher.    My apology to those sandbagged.
content.protection: 7 bolts to LO.
content.location: Second  bolted line from the left on the steep Luna wall.

content.description: Start up the wide crack (wide gear not needed)in the right facing corner into a great finger crack.  Turn the lip at the top and run it a ways up a low angle corner system and easy slabs to the top.  Easier to belay someone or set a gear TR above the vertical corner.
content.protection: standard rack to bd 4
content.location: To the left of the main 5.7 corner by about 40'.  Careful as it cliff's out and sometimes seeps at the base.

climbs.name: Hymie's Last Stand aka  Karin's Route

content.description: This is a really enjoyable face climb on  positive holds.
content.protection: 6 bolts to LO anchors.
content.location: Located on the wide slab to the right of the Nose and north face area. There is a pine tree growing out of this slab. The route starts at a large beech tree part way up the steep slope. Shorter climbers tend to find the crux more difficult.

content.description: Great climbing and one of the most difficult all gear protected routes in New England. The meat of the climb is a V9ish  boulder problem at mid height  involving a series of very powerful opposing side pulls to either a long low percentage dyno ( Will C) or several more difficult face moves (Joe T) to the horizontal.  Blow the last bit before the horizontal and you'll take  a 25' - 30' lob. If the small cam pulls, a bomber offset nut will keep you off the ground.     The route tops out so the anchors are set back from the edge. Bring 6' slings if intending to TR.
content.protection:
Small to medium cams and a #9 HB or DMM offset nut.   All gear was placed free and on lead. 

  DO NOT PLACE ANY PINS OR FIX ANY GEAR ON THIS ROUTE.
content.location: Between  the BBB route and Moe Howard Died For Our Sins.    Right facing corner and flakes to steep face.

content.description: Locate a bolt just above small triangular roof at the base of the cliff. Pass the bolt on moderate 10- to thin cracks up to the main diagonal crack. Follow the crack switching to the higher crack mid route. The climbing here is sustained with a show stopper bouldery crux just below the last bolt.
content.protection: rack from green alien to #4 BD, one bolt on the bottom, one at the top.
content.location: the second to last route on the farthest right wall of the main cliff at stonehouse - look for a bolt just above a small triangular roof on the right side of the cliff.

climbs.name: Down By Law
climbs.fa: Joe Terravecchia, Roberto Benigni (TR). Christian Prellwitz, lead

content.description: This is a  clean slab route with a desperately slippery crux. Wait for cool temps or prepare ye to slide. Bolts are a little spaced due to the scarcity of good clipping stances.
content.protection: 5 bolts to a hemlock tree growing out of the slab.
content.location: 75' right of Hymie's Last Stand. The first bolted route that you see as you emerge from the chimney approaching from the water.

content.description: The left most route on the Don Wall.Easy slab to steep face. I heard that John Goodman soloed this in work boots and a vest.
content.protection: 8 bolts
content.location: Belay at the hemlock tree just right of the Nose.

content.description: This route was recently retro bolted and its a situation where it was well warranted. I've climbed this route pre and post bolts and having solid fixed protection does not detract from the climbing.   Start left of the BBB and climb 10 feet up to the first bolt, move up and left on thin edges and slopers to a ledge, traverse slightly left then back right on steep slopers and jugs to a strange v slot at a roof, layback around the v slot getting your feet on a small ledge below the slot, rest then move up on less than inspiring rock to the chains.
content.protection: the crux and below is sporty bolted, after the v groove I would bring a small rack .4-2.
content.location: Just left of the BBB on the main approach trail to the cliff.

climbs.name: The Day After My Birthday ( is not my birthday mum)

content.description: Climbs the first 3 bolts of Sicilian then heads right to the overhang. Pull the roof crux then up the steep face to rejoin Sicilian at the top.
content.protection: 9 bolts.
content.location: Sicilian Olympics

content.description: Climb to a small birch tree from the gully and launch/reach into a rail followed by sustained climbing on hidden quarts holds until it eases to the anchors.
content.protection: Bolts
content.location: This climb is located in the approach gully on the far let side of the luna wall.

content.description: Locate a bolt about twenty feet up, strategically placed below the beginning of a thin seam. The climbing here is solid 9- but requires a cool head. There is a piton just right of the climbing at head height from the ground but it would do very little for you if you fell above it trying to clip the bolt. After clipping the first bolt, thin fingers lead to a boulder problem crux and a marginal rest on a sloping ledge. From here you can escape left at 8+ or plug gear in a horizontal, step up to a lone bolt and launch into a pumpy thin fight to the chains.
content.protection: two bolts, wires, cams from yellow alien to #3 BD.
content.location: when walking up the approach trail the first very obvious line when you reach the cliff.

content.description: Climbs steep edges and pockets to join the last two bolts on Luna. Sustained.
content.protection: 8 bolts to Luna LO.
content.location: Left most route on the Luna wall. During the summer months this wall goes into the shade around mid morning.

content.description: Fantastic thin face climb.
content.protection: 4 bolts to LO’s
content.location: Located 10’ to the left  of Down By Law.

content.description: Surprisingly fun moves and continuous climbing that is in character with the other routes on the wall. Start slightly right of the first bolt in a short diagonal groove. Move left up the groove and then straight up the face to a rest in the bottom of the crack of Flying Squirrel. From there, continue up to a horizontal and then slightly right up face holds to a short deadpoint crux and another horizontal. The final few moves are easier but not a giveaway.
content.protection: 6 bolts and ring anchors
content.location: Farthest right bolt line on the Luna wall.

content.description:
Stonehouse is arguably the most impressive of the little cliffs in southeastern NH. Situated on the shore of a beautiful clear pond, it is remarkable for this part of the state. There are a good range of routes from 5.5 - 5.13d including 15 bolted routes. The cliff is composed of pegmatitic granite and is about 100' at its tallest. It generally faces east and northeast making it a good afternoon destination in hot weather. There's also a great swimming hole along the access trail.

 ATTENTION: The cliff and the surrounding 241 acres was purchased in 2010 by the Trust for Public Land, Strafford Rivers Conservancy, New Hampshire Fish and Game, the Town of Barrington and other partners. The conservation of this land is the result of years of hard work. After decades of access issues this has been a gift to all who value this natural resource. Remember, this could just as easily have been a housing development. Please treat the area with respect and do your part to keep it clean. Pack out all of your trash. Better yet, make the extra effort and pack out what others have left behind. Answer nature's call far from the shores of the pond and trails and bury any human waste.
